Subsequently , Judge PERSON brought an action for defamation against the applicant company under section CARDINAL of LAW and LAW , and requested that the applicant company be ordered to pay compensation and retract the following statements made in the article , which she claimed amounted to a statement that she had grossly misused her office as a judge :

Judge PERSON alleges in the judgment – without giving any reasons – that the asylum seeker was driven by the basest motives .

“ Judge PERSON acquits the security officer . Of course , if she has doubts as to the defendant ’s guilt , she has to do so . But this judge and her lay assessors are in no doubt as to the woman ’s guilt . They have unfinished business with the NORP woman and attribute the basest intentions to her – without furnishing any proof . ”
Judge PERSON had no doubt about the woman ’s guilt .
The judge ignored relevant evidence and delivered a scandalous judgment ( “ The judgment fails to give rise to a scandal . ” )

CARDINAL . On DATE the first hearing in the defamation proceedings was held . The applicant company argued that the impugned statements were true and sought to prove the truth of those statements by asking the court to call several witnesses and admit as evidence the files of the proceedings concerning PERSON ’s asylum request and the criminal proceedings against PERSON It considered that by publishing the impugned statements it had merely expressed criticism , protected by the freedom of speech , which had not concerned the acquittal itself but rather the way in which the victim of the crime had been treated in the written version of the judgment , which had neglected important evidence and had accused the victim , PERSON , of having been a prostitute .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant company sought the disqualification of Judge PERSON , the judge assigned to the media proceedings , for bias . It submitted that the lawyer representing the claimant , PERSON , had also represented PERSON in the past in court proceedings . As Judge PERSON had to decide on a case in which her previous lawyer was acting as representative of CARDINAL of the parties , there was reasonable doubt that she would not decide the case objectively . The president of ORG dismissed the motion on DATE and held that the issue raised by the applicant was not sufficient to give rise to doubt that Judge PERSON would not decide the case objectively .

CARDINAL . On DATE a further hearing was held in the defamation proceedings . The hearing was adjourned in order to hear CARDINAL witnesses proposed by the applicant company . ORG refused to hear other witnesses proposed by the applicant company , as it considered that those persons could not make any statements relevant to the proceedings . The applicant company had sought to call NORP , who had been PERSON ’s lawyer in the criminal proceedings , in order to clarify the meaning of statements that PERSON had given during her examination as a witness which had been recorded on video in order to prevent her as the victim having to face the accused ( kontradiktorische Einvernahme ) . This request was refused by ORG on the grounds that the transcript of PERSON ’s examination had been included in the case file and therefore no additional witness was required .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG held another hearing in the defamation proceedings in which it examined CARDINAL of the witnesses proposed by the applicant company . The third witness proposed did not appear . On DATE ORG found against the applicant company . It held that the impugned statements had constituted defamation under LAW and that PERSON was therefore entitled to compensation , which it set at MONEY ( ORG ) . It also ordered the applicant company to publish a summary of the judgment .

CARDINAL . ORG found that the contents of the article had given a biased account of the taking of evidence at the trial of PERSON , taking the side of PERSON and characterising any statement of a witness which did not coincide with hers as lacking credibility . According to the article , the judge had acted arbitrarily and out of racist motives and had disregarded evidence produced , whereas the rape asserted by PERSON had been described as proven and the assessment of evidence by ORG as absurd . Such an account was not an objective critique of the judgment .

CARDINAL . As regards the criminal proceedings against ORG , ORG observed that : ( a ) they had been discontinued by ORG ; and ( b ) upon a subsequent decision by ORG had been committed for trial ( PERSON in den LOC ) . Following CARDINAL hearings at which a total of CARDINAL witnesses had been heard , the tape recording of the questioning of the victim had been viewed in part by the court and a confrontation between CARDINAL witnesses and PERSON had taken place , the court had acquitted the accused .

CARDINAL . In its judgment of CARDINAL DATE the court had found that it could not be excluded that the sexual intercourse which had taken place between PERSON and the accused had been consensual , in accordance with the version of events given by the accused and which had , to some extent , been corroborated by the statements of witnesses who had seen the accused and PERSON together in a coffee shop in town . PERSON ’s assertion that she had been the victim of an assault had not been excluded but because it contradicted the statements of witnesses it had been considered to be partially implausible . The accused had not therefore been acquitted because his innocence had been proven but rather on the basis of the principle of in dubio pro reo .

CARDINAL . ORG also referred to one passage of the written judgment on which the article had put much emphasis , namely a reference to a statement by PERSON made in the course of her questioning as a witness to the effect that she had previously been engaged in prostitution in her country of origin , which the judgment stated had allowed inferences to be drawn with regard to the statement by the accused that the witness might have become involved with him because she expected DATE for whatever reason – to gain some advantage .

CARDINAL . ORG found that the applicant company had not succeeded in proving the truth of the impugned statements . From the case file concerning the proceedings against PERSON and , in particular , the written version of the judgment it appeared that Judge PERSON had dealt with all the evidence taken and had assessed each item of evidence extensively . Therefore , it could not be established that Judge PERSON had made base insinuations ( üble DATE ) or disregarded evidence . The judgment had clearly indicated the court ’s reluctance to accept the version of events given by PERSON also . In addition , the indication of PERSON having been a prostitute in the past had been based on a statement from the questioning of that witness and had not been made up out of thin air . CARDINAL . The accusation that a judge , who was under the duty to act objectively and impartially , had without any factual basis and out of racist motives deliberately disregarded evidence in order to acquit an accused from the same country ( inländischen ORG ) had to be qualified as defamation and there was hardly a more severe accusation which could be levied against a judge . The term scandal of justice was a value judgement , which , however , was based on assertions of fact which had been disproven in the proceedings .

CARDINAL . Insofar as the applicant company had relied on LAW , ORG referred to the case of GPE and PERSON v. GPE ( DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL ) , and observed that the press had the right and the duty to impart information on matters of public interest , including questions concerning the functioning of the justice system , and to criticise any shortcomings found , but in doing so it had to be mindful of the special role of the judiciary in society . It was therefore necessary to protect public confidence in the judiciary against destructive attacks that were essentially unfounded . Taking these principles into account , the sharp critique of Judge PERSON in the impugned article , which had lacked any sufficient factual basis , had been excessive .

CARDINAL . Taking the gravity of the attacks on the claimant ’s professional reputation , the broad public attention the article had received and the consequences it had had for the claimant , ORG found that the amount of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL in compensation was appropriate .
